awd_titl_txt: LSAMP BD: North Carolina State University Preparing Researchers of the Future (PROF) NC-LSAMP
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM
disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and competitiveness of STEM
graduate students from historically underrepresented minority populations, with emphasis on STEM doctoral matriculation and completion.

The 2018-2020 North Carolina LSAMP (NC-LSAMP) BD program will recruit twelve (12)alumni from LSAMP institutions nationwide for STEM postbaccalaureate studies at North Carolina State University  Student support in the form of stipends and cost of education are provided for two years for each student. The institution commits to assisting the students financially through completion of the STEM doctoral program.  NCSU's strategy focuses on the student and develops a comprehensive supportive program that will increase the student's confidence in being a strong and productive STEM researcher; increases the student's connection to their research advisor; increases their ability to assess and contribute towards their research topic; increases their connection to the university and surrounding community; and, increases their overall well-being. 

The project activities adds new knowledge to the literature related to the impact of proximal influences on the persistence of minority graduate students. In addition, the proposal will add new insights into strategies that lead to positive outcomes during the interactions within the different proximal influences.  At the conclusion of this program, the BD participants will be armed with robust and resilient strategies that will allow them to maintain their persistence through the Ph.D. degree. Our faculty will be instructed in new mentoring techniques to help improve their interactions with their graduate students. Our study will be the first to explore the impact of an advisory panel for each graduate student to improve the overall well-being of the graduate student and their persistence through the graduate program.

Evaluative activities will assess outcomes of students' accomplishments relating to retention, degree completion, and career progress. Social psychological outcomes related to career goals and expectations related to STEM identity development will also be assessed. Outcomes will be disseminated broadly through the institution's website, scholarly journals, and presentations at STEM professional conferences. These efforts will increase the diversity of STEM academic leadership and contribute to the growing literature on broadening participation in STEM at the graduate and post-graduate level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Preparing Researchers of the Future (PROF) Bridge to the Doctorate Program at NCSU proposed a holistic structure that addressed the factors affecting the pursuit, matriculation, and completion of STEM doctoral degrees by students from racial and ethnic underrepresented demographics. As part of our project, we developed several programs that addressed recruitment, retention, and faculty interactions/mentoring.

Robust Recruitment: BD leadership along with the Graduate School diversity recruiters and the College of Engineering (COE) diversity recruitment efforts, engaged in a number of recruitment opportunities at local meetings, national and regional conferences, and specialty conferences where LSAMP students would exclusively attend. We also targeted LSAMP alliance institutions in North Carolina, other states such as Florida, Alabama, and South Carolina, and Puerto Rico. BD fliers were provided to other University staff that were attending targeted recruiting events. In addition, electronic fliers were sent to LSAMP directors across the USA. Recruiting trips that directly targeted LSAMP member alliance institutions went beyond just informing students about our BD program. Co-PIs took the opportunity to inform potential applicants about best practices in developing a STEM graduate school application and graduate school expectations. Topics of our presentations included: What’s in the mind of Faculty when reviewing a graduate school application, How to write a personal statement, Typical funding opportunities for graduate school, Transitioning from undergraduate to graduate school environment, Expectations of Faculty advisors of their graduate students. Co-PI Ducoste also took the opportunity to meet with faculty at these institutions to explore potential research collaborations that would foster a stronger relationship between the two institutions.

Orientation: A four day summer orientation workshop was delivered prior to the first year of the BD fellows. Various workshops facilitated by the BD leadership team, faculty, and professionals on topics including: transitioning from undergraduate to graduate school, managing the PhD process, understanding learning and personality styles, growth mindset, imposter syndrome, and Individual Development Plans. Additionally, Dr. Donna O. Johnson-Mackey facilitated her Guaranteed 4.0 Learning System. Several campus offices participated, including the Counseling Center, Office of Institutional Equity and Diversity, Disability Services Office, Graduate School, and Libraries hosted training on how to utilize their databases to literature searches. Our strategy was to deliver significant successful graduate school best practices from an introductory perspective that would help graduate students be successful not only in their first year but also throughout their graduate training.

Monthly Meetings: Continued support was provided to students through monthly meetings. We were able to dive deeper into some of the orientation topics, and implement activities such as IDPs. We also introduced new topics including: written communication (Avoiding Plagiarism), financial planning, personal wellness, oral communication (presenting research with a public audience), leveraging LinkedIn for professional branding, networking, and job searches, exploring international research opportunities and non-academic careers, developing a mentoring network.

Fellowship Preparation Program: Fellows applied for the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) along with other competitive fellowships (Ford Fellowship, GEM, National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate Fellowship). A comprehensive preparation program was developed, which leveraged existing support workshops offered by the Graduate School and Department of Civil, Construction, and Environmental Engineering (CCEE). Fellows enrolled in a four week Fellowship and Grants Workshop facilitated by the Graduate School. We then incorporated two panels during this time. One panel featured former fellowship winners to provide their perspective on strategies to create a winning application. The second panel consisted of NSF program managers and faculty who have reviewed GRFP applications. Fellows were then given deadlines to submit drafts of their documents that were then reviewed by BD leadership and other volunteers. In addition, Fellows were invited to attend a GRFP boot camp hosted by the Graduate School and GRFP workshop hosted by the CCEE department.

Faculty Mentoring Workshop: Frameworks of the Appreciative Advising and Center for the Improvement of Mentored Experiences (CIMER) models were utilized to develop a two-part faculty mentoring workshop. The workshop was organized by BD Co-PIs, Ducoste, Wright, and Charles as well as Dr. Olgha Qaqish formerly of the NC State College of Engineering (COE) Office of Faculty Advancement (OFA). Ducoste and Charles attended the Appreciative Advising training at Florida Atlantic University and Qaqish is a facilitator and trainer of the CIMER model. We discussed the various roles of faculty in academia (advisor, mentor, coach, trainer), the importance of personalized mentoring, and the value of creating a diverse learning environment. We then introduced two mentoring models (Appreciative Advising and CIMER) to inform faculty of various mentoring approaches that can be used when working with their students. The Appreciative Advising model, consists of six phases: Disarm, Discovery, Dream, Design, Deliver, and Don’t Settle, and the CIMER model, consists of Maintaining Effective Communication, Fostering Independence, Understanding Equity and Inclusion, Aligning Expectations with IDP, Assessing Understanding, Cultivating Ethical Behavior, Promoting Professional Development.
